messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Computational Complexity of Schr√∂dinger Operators

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study computational problems related to the Schr√∂dinger operator H=‚àíŒî+VùêªŒîùëâH=-\Delta+V in the real space under the condition that (i) the potential function VùëâV is smooth and has its value and derivative bounded within some polynomial of nùëõn and (ii) VùëâV only consists of ùí™‚Äã(1)ùí™1\mathcal{O}\!\left({1}\right)-body interactions. We prove that (i) simulating the dynamics generated by the Schr√∂dinger operator implements universal quantum computation, i.e., it is BQP-hard, and (ii) estimating the ground energy of the Schr√∂dinger operator is as hard as estimating that of local Hamiltonians with no sign problem (a.k.a. stoquastic Hamiltonians), i.e., it is StoqMA-complete. This result is particularly intriguing because the ground energy problem for general bosonic Hamiltonians is known to be QMA-hard and it is widely believed that StoqMA‚ääQMAStoqMAQMA\textsf{StoqMA}\varsubsetneq\textsf{QMA}.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Why quantum chemistry is hard",
        "Proof of the fundamental gap conjecture",
        "The power of quantum systems on a line",
        "Schr√∂dinger operators with magnetic fields. I. general interactions",
        "The acrobatics of BQP",
        "A review on quantum approximate optimization algorithm and its variants",
        "Quantum algorithms for quantum chemistry and quantum materials science",
        "Merlin-Arthur games and stoquastic complexity",
        "Schrieffer‚ÄìWolff transformation for quantum many-body systems",
        "The complexity of stoquastic local Hamiltonian problems",
        "On complexity of the quantum Ising model",
        "Eigenvalue problems",
        "QMA-complete problems",
        "Monte Carlo simulation of stoquastic Hamiltonians",
        "Complexity of stoquastic frustration-free Hamiltonians",
        "Improved hardness results for the guided local Hamiltonian problem",
        "Universal computation by multiparticle quantum walk",
        "The Bose-Hubbard model is QMA-complete",
        "Quantum simulation of real-space dynamics",
        "Quantum Langevin dynamics for optimization",
        "Complexity classification of local Hamiltonian problems",
        "Universal quantum Hamiltonians",
        "Spectral asymptotics in the semi-classical limit",
        "Partial differential equations, volume 19",
        "Simulating physics with computers",
        "Quantum simulation",
        "Quantum Hamiltonian complexity",
        "Encoding a qubit in an oscillator",
        "On the determination of a differential equation from its spectral function",
        "Dequantizing the quantum singular value transformation: hardness and applications to quantum chemistry and the quantum PCP conjecture",
        "The Heisenberg representation of quantum computers",
        "Synthesis of quantum superpositions by quantum computation",
        "Modern condensed matter physics",
        "Semi-classical analysis for the Schr√∂dinger operator and applications, volume 1336",
        "The local Hamiltonian problem on a line with eight states is QMA-complete",
        "Introduction to spectral theory: With applications to Schr√∂dinger operators, volume 113",
        "Quantum-Merlin-Arthur‚Äìcomplete problems for stoquastic Hamiltonians and Markov matrices",
        "Local Hamiltonian problem with succinct ground state is MA-complete",
        "Accreditation of analogue quantum simulators",
        "BQP-completeness of scattering in scalar quantum field theory",
        "Quantum algorithms for quantum field theories",
        "BQP-complete problems concerning mixing properties of classical random walks on sparse graphs",
        "Perturbation theory for linear operators, volume 132",
        "The complexity of the local Hamiltonian problem",
        "Fermionic linear optics and matchgates",
        "Computational supremacy in quantum simulation",
        "Classical and quantum computation",
        "Computational chemistry",
        "Quantum Hamiltonian descent",
        "Expanding hardware-efficiently manipulable Hilbert space via Hamiltonian embedding",
        "On quantum speedups for nonconvex optimization via quantum tunneling walks",
        "A quantum-classical performance separation in nonconvex optimization",
        "A remark on eigenvalue splittings for one-dimensional double-well Hamiltonians",
        "The complexity of quantum spin systems on a two-dimensional square lattice",
        "The complexity of antiferromagnetic interactions and 2D lattices",
        "Simulating quantum field theory with a quantum computer",
        "Methods of modern mathematical physics, volume 1",
        "Schr√∂dinger semigroups",
        "On learning rates and Schr√∂dinger operators",
        "Computational complexity of interacting electrons and fundamental limitations of density functional theory",
        "Classical simulation of noninteracting-fermion quantum circuits",
        "Quantum computers that can be simulated classically in polynomial time",
        "Guidable local Hamiltonian problems with implications to heuristic ans√§tze state preparation and the quantum PCP conjecture",
        "Strongly universal Hamiltonian simulators",
        "Quantum algorithms for escaping from saddle points"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Computational Complexity of Schr√∂dinger Operators, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
